channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Cyprus backs 'painful' bailout deal
item.description: The Cypriot government defends a 10bn-euro bailout deal to save its banks from collapse, amid warnings the island faces deep recession.

item.title: Cameron targets migrant benefits
item.description: Tougher curbs on immigrants who want to claim unemployment benefits in the UK have been set out by Prime Minister David Cameron.

item.title: Britons struggling in snow's wake
item.description: Britons tell of their struggles to cope in the unseasonably cold weather after snow hit the UK, leaving thousands of homes without power.

item.title: Fears over launch of NHS 111 line
item.description: Doctors are questioning the safety of a new non-emergency NHS telephone advice line in England.

item.title: MI5 chief to step down next month
item.description: The head of MI5, Sir Jonathan Evans, is to step down next month, Home Secretary Theresa May tells MPs.

item.title: Border agency condemned over backlog
item.description: The UK Border Agency is still plagued by backlogs of unresolved immigration cases, says the Home Affairs Committee of MPs.

item.title: Science adviser warns of more floods
item.description: The UK government's chief scientist says that there is already enough CO2 in the atmosphere for there to be more floods, drought and storms over the next 25 years.

item.title: US army hands over Bagram prison
item.description: The US army hands over to Afghanistan the notorious Bagram jail, resolving an issue that has strained ties between the countries.

item.title: Anonymity risk from phone place data
item.description: A study of mobile phone data - used by advertisers or even released publicly - reveals that individuals can be identified using only four location points.

item.title: Anger at delayed IPCC Duggan report
item.description: The police watchdog has been described as being "not fit for purpose", by Mark Duggan's barrister.

item.title: No confidence in Gove, union says
item.description: A teaching union has passed a motion of no confidence in Education Secretary Michael Gove and the chief inspector of England's schools, Sir Michael Wilshaw.

item.title: Harry lined up for six-day US tour
item.description: Prince Harry is to tour the US in May to help promote the rehabilitation of injured American and UK troops, St James's Palace says.

item.title: Accused 'not heard of Joss Stone'
item.description: One of the men accused of plotting to murder the singer Joss Stone tells a jury he had not heard of her before being charged.

item.title: UK teen's app bought for 'millions'
item.description: Yahoo has acquired an app created by a UK teenager for "dozens of millions" of pounds.

item.title: Triangular flapjack banned at school
item.description: Triangle-shaped flapjacks are banned at an Essex school after one was thrown and hurt a pupil.

item.title: Markets fall despite Cyprus deal
item.description: European and US stock markets reverse early gains and head lower, despite the agreement of a bailout deal for Cyprus.

item.title: Profit at Big Five banks 'wiped out'
item.description: The major UK banks saw their core profits for 2012 wiped out by a mix of regulations and their own mistakes, a KPMG report says.

item.title: Proposals on England-only law votes
item.description: Legislation which affects just England should normally need backing by a majority of MPs who represent English constituencies, a report says.

item.title: BBC interview splendid, says Boris
item.description: London mayor Boris Johnson says BBC presenter Eddie Mair did a "splendid job" in questioning him about his personal life and "integrity" during an interview.

item.title: Young cancer deaths halved since 70s
item.description: The number of teenagers and young adults dying from cancer in the UK has halved since the 1970s, according to a report from Cancer Research UK.

item.title: Amniotic fluid 'may heal babies'
item.description: Doctors believe amniotic fluid may hold the key to healing a gut disease which can be fatal in premature babies.

item.title: Disruptive pupil behaviour 'on rise'
item.description: A teachers' union says the number of pupils in the UK with behavioural and mental health problems is on the rise.

item.title: Gove reforms 'neglecting pupils'
item.description: Education Secretary Michael Gove is accused of damaging children's schooling by pushing through "wrong-headed" reforms.

item.title: Apple buys indoor-mapping company
item.description: Apple makes its first significant push into indoor mapping as it acquires US firm Wifislam for a reported $20m (£13m).

item.title: Nokia and Google clash on web video
item.description: Finnish phone firm Nokia and Google have clashed over a plan to create free-to-use video encoding technology.

item.title: Falcons 'rapidly evolved hunter skill'
item.description: Falcons rapidly evolved their renowned hunting skills in an evolutionary race to survive, a study finds.

item.title: Down's syndrome brain protein loss
item.description: The lack of a protein in Down's syndrome brains could be the cause of learning and memory problems, says a US study.

item.title: iPlayer debut for Peter Kay sitcom
item.description: Comedian Peter Kay is to make his first BBC One sitcom with a show that will go out on TV only after making its debut on the BBC iPlayer.

item.title: Timberlake album dethrones Bowie
item.description: Justin Timberlake goes straight to the top of the UK chart with his first album for seven years, knocking David Bowie's comeback LP off the summit.

item.title: A boy named North West
item.description: Kanye West wants to call his son North, reports say. If he does, he's following an established tradition.

item.title: Chess and 18th Century artificial intelligence
item.description: Adam Gopnik considers how an 18th Century chess robot - the mechanical Turk - was more than just an elaborate hoax.

item.title: England can save final Test - Gooch
item.description: England believe they can save the final Test against New Zealand in Auckland, says batting coach Graham Gooch.

item.title: England are scared - Montenegro boss
item.description: Montenegro coach Branko Brnovic says England are scared of Tuesday's World Cup Group H qualifier in Podgorica.

item.title: Taylor backs retrospective action
item.description: Professional Footballers' Association chief Gordon Taylor believes rules on retrospective action should be changed.

item.title: Watkins & Grainger could reunite
item.description: Olympic champion Anna Watkins says she wants to team up with Katherine Grainger if she decides to return to rowing.

item.title: Every team wants fighting drivers, not pussycats
item.description: David Coulthard gives his view on Vettel, Webber and Red Bull's handling of the incident-packed Malaysian Grand Prix

item.title: Casualty actor has ear bitten off
item.description: Actor Clive Mantle, the former Casualty star who now appears in Game of Thrones, has part of his ear bitten off in an attack in a Newcastle hotel.

item.title: Museum collection threatened by fire
item.description: A fire has broken out in a building in Southwark which houses a library, a museum and the council's one stop shop.

item.title: Engineers battle to restore power
item.description: Fears expressed that it could take weeks to restore mains power to some of the areas affected by March storms.

item.title: SPL faces £1.7m 'TV dispute' claim
item.description: The Scottish Premier League faces a £1.7m damages claim over its bid to stop a pub group screening live matches via a Polish broadcaster.

item.title: Hundreds suffer effects of snowstorm
item.description: Hundred of farmers and rural residents are still suffering the effects of the heavy snow and strong winds in Northern Ireland.

item.title: Name of fire victim is released
item.description: A 54-year-old woman has died in a fire at a bungalow in Kinawley, County Fermanagh,

item.title: Minister warns on health spending
item.description: Health Minister Mark Drakeford refuses to rule out the possibility some boards could fail to balance their books, but warns he will want explanations if they do.

item.title: Snow could return in time for Easter
item.description: Snow which caused widespread disruption in north and mid Wales on Friday and the weekend could return in time for Easter, forecasters warn.

item.title: South African soldiers killed in CAR
item.description: Thirteen South African soldiers were killed by Central African Republic rebels at the weekend, it is announced, while President Francois Bozize is said to have fled to Cameroon.

item.title: EU suspends most Zimbabwe sanctions
item.description: The European Union suspends sanctions against 81 officials and eight firms in Zimbabwe following what it called a "successful" constitutional referendum.

item.title: HK court denies maids residency
item.description: Hong Kong's government wins an appeal against a ruling that could have allowed foreign domestic helpers to apply for residency in the city.

item.title: Communal rioting spreads in Burma
item.description: Mosques and houses are ransacked in central Burma, the latest in a series of incidents since sectarian violence broke out in Meiktila town.

item.title: Italy court considers Knox retrial
item.description: Italy's highest court hears an appeal by prosecutors over the acquittal of Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito over the murder of Meredith Kercher.

item.title: Army tackles Ukraine snow chaos
item.description: Armoured personnel carriers are used in the Ukrainian capital Kiev to drag buses and other vehicles out of snowdrifts.

item.title: Cocaine found in shipment of bricks
item.description: Colombian police find 500kg (1,100lb) of cocaine hidden inside a consignment of bricks in the northern port city of Cartagena.

item.title: Mexico finds ancient playing fields
item.description: Three pre-Columbian pelota courts at least 1,000 years old are uncovered at the Tajin archaeological site in Mexico by experts using laser scanners.

item.title: Blast wounds Syria rebel commander
item.description: The man who established and once commanded the rebel Free Syrian Army (FSA), Col Riad al-Asaad, is badly hurt by an explosion in the country's east.

item.title: Israel to resume tax payments to PA
item.description: Israel is to resume the transfer of tax revenues it collects on behalf of the Palestinian Authority, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office says.

item.title: Bloomberg in $12m gun control drive
item.description: New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg commits $12m of his own money to a national advertising campaign pushing for tougher gun controls.

item.title: US spring snowstorm pushes east
item.description: A spring storm that brought as much as 17in (43 cm) of snow to the US Midwest and is blamed for two deaths moves toward the populous East Coast.

item.title: Day in pictures: 25 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 25 March

item.title: In Pictures: Rowena Cade's theatre
item.description: The Minack Theatre prepares for its new season

item.title: In pictures: Earth Hour around the world
item.description: Images from around the world of Earth Hour

item.title: Week in pictures: 16-22 March 2013
item.description: A selection of the best photos from the news

item.title: Day in pictures: 22 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 22 March

item.title: In pictures: Lives in limbo on India-Bangladesh border
item.description: Alakananda Nag explores the India-Bangladesh border

item.title: In Pictures: Ecology photo contest's winners
item.description: A stunning display of nature's diversity

item.title: In pictures: Obama in Israel
item.description: Obama's first visit to Israel as president

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: Labour MP Frank Field is asking an urgent question on immigrants’ rights.

item.title: VIDEO: French troops tracking Islamists in Mali
item.description: Islamist rebels have attacked Gao in northern Mali, officials say.

item.title: VIDEO: Johnson defends 'nasty' questions
item.description: The mayor of London Boris Johnson has defended BBC presenter Eddie Mair's right to ask tough questions. Mr Mair described Mr Johnson as "a nasty piece of work" during an interview.

item.title: VIDEO: UK gas demand driving new exploration
item.description: The increased price of gas and improved drilling techniques has led to new areas being explored and extracted.

item.title: VIDEO: Engineers try to restore island power
item.description: Engineers are trying to restore power to residents and businesses on the Scottish island of Arran which has endured heavy snow and high winds.

item.title: VIDEO: Buddhists target Sri Lanka's Muslims
item.description: Muslims in Sri Lanka have voiced concerns about a growing number of anti-Muslim protests and attacks, carried out by hardline Buddhist groups.

item.title: VIDEO: Buble on his 'happy' break-up song
item.description: Singer Michael Buble has been speaking to the BBC's Tim Muffett about the idea for his new song, It's a Beautiful Day - a break-up song with a difference.

item.title: VIDEO: Fisherman: 'I proceeded to drown'
item.description: Irish fisherman James McCarthy has described the moment he nearly died after falling into near freezing waters in the Gulf of Alaska.

item.title: VIDEO: Audi crash like an 'explosion'
item.description: The collision of an Audi TT into the side of house in Lowestoft was "similar to an explosion" said a neighbour.

item.title: The people who think they tune in to dead voices
item.description: The people who say they can tune in to dead voices

item.title: Has Street View changed the way we act?
item.description: Has Google Street View changed the way people behave?

item.title: Why such a fuss about extinction?
item.description: Is extinction always a bad thing?

item.title: How Beeching cuts divided Yorkshire
item.description: How Beeching railway cuts of 50 years ago divided Yorkshire

item.title: The gay airman who took on the US military
item.description: The first man who broke the US military's ban

item.title: The rise of the community service
item.description: Why the health service will never be the same again

item.title: Your visions of the future
item.description: Imagining the future without words

item.title: Second chance Suede
item.description: Older, wiser but still hoping to get under people's skin

item.title: Using games to teach physics
item.description: How games can make it easier to learn

item.title: Should we despair at the kids of today?
item.description: Should we despair at today's teens?

item.title: Cyprus's devastating rescue
item.description: Cyprus's rescue won't feel like one to its people, says Robert Peston
